name: Silent Hunter 5®: Battle of the Atlantic
description: Step behind the periscope of a German U-boat and take on the Allied Forces in famous battles across the vast Atlantic Ocean and Mediterranean Sea. The best-selling submarine series of all time continues with the highly anticipated Silent Hunter: Battle of the Atlantic.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows® XP (Service Pack 3), Windows Vista® (Service Pack 2), Windows® 7 Processor: Intel® Core™2 Duo E4400 2 GHz / AMD Athlon™ 64 X2 4000+ 2.1 GHz or higher (Intel Core™2 Quad Q6600 2.4 GHz / AMD Athlon 64 X2 5200+ 2.6 GHz or higher recommended) Memory: 1 GB (Windows XP) / 2 GB (Windows Vista, Windows 7) (2 GB recommended) Graphics: 512 MB DirectX® 9.0c-compliant video card(*see supported list) DirectX®:  Hard Drive: 10 GB (15 GB recommended) Sound: DirectX 9.0c-compliant sound card Peripherals Supported: Windows-compliant mouse, keyboard Internet Connection:  256 kbps Broadband connection (512 kbps connection or better recommended) Supported Video Cards at Time of Release:  NVIDIA GeForce 8800GT / 9 / GTX 200 series  ATI Radeon HD 2600 / HD 3000 / HD 4000 / HD 5000 series  NVIDIA SLI & ATI Crossfire

reviews.review_text: This game is an incomplete piece of crap. Beautiful in theory, its final execution is spectacularly underperforming and inept in almost every way. More importantly, the host of bugs that leave the final product quality trapped in what should rightly be the early development phase are now permanent, since Ubisoft has long since stopped providing any fixes or customer support for it. I don't blame them; no one likes to be repeatedly reminded about their shoddy workmanship. On the other hand, they shouldn't be asking money for it either.  Thanks to insanely die-hard fans of the series, there are numerous mods available online to improve the game. Still, you shouldn't have to clean up someone else's mess. Stick to SH 3 and 4, two really nice games for this genre.

Ubisoft never finished this game, before or after release. The crew are always relaxing, even when you order battlestations. The campaign doesn't go past 1943. You don't get a compass. You don't get rudder controls. There is no working TDC. You'll be lucky if your save files don't corrupt after your first mission. This game is worth $3 or $4, tops.

This could have been amazing. It could have raised the bar, so that twenty year old Sub Sim's weren't the current goto contemporary simulator in the field. But Ubisoft Poland dropped the ball by removing everything that made Silent Hunter great. There's no level of customization of crew and equipment anywhere near the older versions. There's no developing your crew, or betterment of your men, instead you get derpy yellow ! quest giver's without quests who just repeat the same lines about their family, and usually bug out and insist they have something new to say but repeat the same thing. This could have been great, the graphics are really good for it's era, even still, but the let down is in the depth and the missions. You'd think removing ALL the customization and RPG aspects would have been to allow them to add more missions and more game depth, but nope. Oh, and all versions are censored German versions where nothing historic will be depicted on your otherwise authentic U-boat.

I really tried to like this game but it was unplayable from the start. Right out of the gate it wouldn't even load because UPlay reported that some Ubisoft service was down. I finally worked around that by downloading UPlay from Ubi's website and launching it that way. The tutorial in this game is horrible -- it shows you how to shoot at surface targets that don't move. It doesn't enable control panels that you're supposed to use during the tutorial. At no point does it teach you about diving your submarine, how to operate submerged (i.e. running out of oxygen, depleting your batteries, etc). The first mission brief after the tutorial asked me to choose one of two missions and neither one was available to select on the map. After restarting the campaign a few times they finally showed up so I selected one where I needed to sink some merchant vessels. While on that mission I surfaced my submarine but the game thought I was still submerged (even though I'm walking around on deck). Because the game thinks I'm submerged my deck crew won't come up topside and my CO2 is continuing to accumulate. After sinking a few ships I check my mission status and find that it has not recorded any of my kills as progress towards the mission goal.   I spent more time restarting, saving/loading, and searching forum posts for workarounds than I spent actually playing the game. This is not even an alpha game at this stage.

I loved the Silent Hunter series, and I was excited to play this title when I first heard of it. Sadly, this game does NOT live up to the high standards set by its predecessors.  The main flaws include the following: Uplay DRM to play the game. Game-breaking bugs and flaws that will sometimes prevent you from even progressing, or on occasion, will reset your progress to a much earlier point. -Examples of this include:  -When opening the periscope view the game instantly crashes to desktop with no crash dump, report, or warning.  -Some enemy units will disappear in full view of the player without explanation or warning.  -Certain story objectives are not acomplishable due to the game not tallying kills properly.  The main reasons to enjoy your time in this game: All gamebreaking bugs aside, the game looks beautiful, and is a good platform for mods (assuming you are allowed to, I wouldn't know as I have only played the stock game). The mechanics from the old Silent Hunter games are somewhat present, but the game is much easier than it's predecessors.  Overall: Don't buy this game, buy Silent Hunter IV or Silent Hunter III

I honestly was very surprised at the graphics, mechanism, and overall design of this game. It's not one of those games that make you sit in one place in the sub. In this game, you can interact with the most important aspects of being a World War Two submarine simulation, such as the crew, the periscopes, and the deck weaponry. I recommend it for those hardcore subsimmers. You haven't played a good subsim without at least trying this gam.

This game is great. This game is buggy. This game is the cake without icing. This game is worth a purchase. If you have the patience for simulation games, this one is a little bit of a lighter load to carry and can be mastered quite easily. The bugs will rear their ugly heads from time to time, most are merely amusing. Like the torpedo explosions that send ships flying hundreds of yards vertically upwards. Some will frustrate you to no end, like missing mission specific ships.  Overall, if its on sale pick it up. Remember, the more people who buy these games means Silent Hunter 6 has a greater chance of being made. These types of games rock, but this one just rolls.
